title: Simion Bughici
text:
Simion Bughici (b. Simon David, December 14, 1914 – February 1, 1997) was a <a href="Romania">Romania</a>n <a href="communist">communist</a> politician who served as the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Foreign%20Affairs%20%28Romania%29">Minister of Foreign Affairs of Romania</a>.
Life and career.
Bughici was born in <a href="Ia%C8%99i">Iași</a> to a Jewish family of <a href="klezmer">klezmer</a> musicians; his father and two brothers perished during the June 1941 <a href="Ia%C8%99i%20pogrom">Iași pogrom</a>. He joined the banned <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Romania">Communist Party of Romania</a> in 1933. During <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, Bughici was imprisoned at <a href="Vapniarka%20concentration%20camp">Vapniarka concentration camp</a> in <a href="Transnistria">Transnistria</a>. He served as an Ambassador of Romania to <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> in 1949–1952. In July 1952, he was appointed <a href="Minister%20of%20Foreign%20Affairs%20%28Romania%29">Minister of Foreign Affairs of Romania</a>, replacing <a href="Ana%20Pauker">Ana Pauker</a>, who was sacked by the communist leadership aided by <a href="Joseph%20Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a>. The appointment of Bughici disassociated Pauker's downfall from the anti-Semitism widely seen in Eastern Europe at the time. Bughici served as minister until October 1955. During his political career, he also served as the Vice <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Romania">Prime Minister of Romania</a>.
Other offices that he held were that of head of Centrocoop, Minister of the Food Industry and vice president of the Communist Party Control Commission (Colegiul Central de Partid) (1969-1974).
He was married to Ana Friedman, a history teacher and school principal.
